{{Infobox sports season | title = 2009–10 National League B | color = | color text = | league = National League B | sport = [[Ice hockey]] | duration = | no_of_teams = 10 | attendance = | TV = | season = Regular season | season_champs = [[EHC Visp]] | season_champ_name = Best record | second_place = [[EHC Olten]] | MVP = | MVP_link = | top_scorer = [[Dominic Forget]] | top_scorer_link = | promote = | promoted_from = | relegate = | relegate_to = | playoffs = Playoffs | playoffs_link = | playoffs_MVP = | playoffs_MVP_link = | finals = | finals_link = | finals_champ = [[Lausanne HC]] | finals_runner-up = [[EHC Visp]] | finals_MVP = | finals_MVP_link = | seasonslist = | seasonslistnames = | prevseason_link = 2008–09 National League B season | prevseason_year = 2008–09 | nextseason_link = 2010–11 National League B season | nextseason_year = 2010–11 }}{{No footnotes|date=April 2018}} The '''2009–10 National League B season''' was the season played in the [[National League B]], [[Switzerland]]'s second-tier professional ice hockey league, during 2009 and 2010. [[EHC Visp]] won the regular season championship, with a one point edge over second place [[EHC Olten]]. The winner of the playoffs was [[Lausanne HC]], the third-ranked team of the regular season.
==References== [http://www.eliteprospects.com/standings.php?league=NLB&startdate=2009&order=rank Elite Prospects]
{{DEFAULTSORT:2009-10 National League B season}} [[Category:2009–10 in European ice hockey leagues|Switzerland]] [[Category:National League B seasons]] [[Category:2009–10 in Swiss ice hockey]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} '''Amagents Football Club''' is a football club based in the Broadhurst district of [[Gaborone]], Botswana. For the 2010/11 Season they will be playing in the GACFA Second Division. ==Organisation== The club consists of the first team and two youth teams, who play at the Under 17 and Under 15 levels. The first team is coached by Jonathan Laverick, who was appointed in May 2009, the youth teams are managed by William Monene. ==Colours== Amagents play in Black Shirts/Shorts with Orange trimming. The youth teams play in an all white kit. There are currently no shirt sponsors. The youth teams play in Blue, with the kit being donated by Billingham Campus School in the UK. ==Recent history== Amagents had an eventful 2008/9 season moving to Lekhubu Private School after their home ground was demolished for development. Although they led the league at Christmas, the team ended up missing out on promotion after a poor second half of the season. This led to the appointment of a new coach. This led to a strong start to the 2009/10 season, but only a sixth-place finish.
The U17 team gained third place in an international 7-a-Side competition held at [[Maru a Pula School]] in September 2009. Following this success a campaign was launched to organise boots and equipment for the youth team. This campaign was featured in the [[Northern Echo]].{{cite news |last = Fay |first = Chris |title = Botswana Football Team Need kitting Out |pages = |newspaper = The Northern Echo |location = Darlington |date = 28 September 2009 |url = http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/4651803.Football_coach___s_kit_plea_for_bare_footed_players/... |accessdate = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20120515214931/http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/4651803.Football_coach___s_kit_plea_for_bare_footed_players/.../ |archive-date = 15 May 2012 |dead-url = yes |df = dmy-all }}
The club has also featured in raising HIV/AIDS awareness.SARPN Newsflash [http://www.sarpn.org.za/newsflash.php?news_id=7829&archive=1 "Aids activists challenge men to test for HIV"], ''[[The Voice (Botswana)]]''
2009 saw the launch of the club's website, one of the first for any club team in Botswana.Amagents FC [http://www.webteams.co.uk/NewsItems.aspx?team=amagentsfc#id32 "24th September – Amagents FC, One Month Online"] This in turn led to worldwide publicity following an AFP film crew visit and the setting of a YouTube channel carrying match highlights, another first in Botswana. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.webteams.co.uk/amagentsfc Amagents FC Homepage] * [http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/4651803.Football_coach___s_kit_plea_for_bare_footed_players/ Northern Echo Story] [[Category:Football clubs in Botswana]] [[Category:Football clubs in Gaborone]] {{Botswana-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Bayamon Soccer Complex | nickname = | image = Bayamon Soccer Complex II sign.jpg | fullname = | address = Calle Quintana; Route 5, intersection with Route 199 | location = [[Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] | coordinates = {{Coord|18.3662921|-66.1664378|type:landmark|name=Bayamon Soccer Complex|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = February 12, 2011http://www.municipiodebayamon.com/inauguracion-bayamon-soccer-complex/ | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Municipio de Bayamón | operator = Municipio de Bayamón | surface = Artificial turf (Field 1)
Grass (Field 2 & 3) | construction_cost = $6 miilion | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = '''Current:'''
[[Bayamon FC|Bayamón Futbol Club]] ([[Puerto Rico Soccer League|PRSL]]) (2011–)
'''Former:''' | seating_capacity = 1,000 (Field 1)
250 (Field 2)
750 (Field 3) | dimensions = }} The '''Bayamon Soccer Complex''' is a complex of 2 soccer fields and one 1,000-capacity stadium located in [[Bayamon, Puerto Rico]] that is host to several teams of the [[San Juan–Caguas–Guaynabo metropolitan area]].Youth, middle school, high school, and adult recreational soccer is held at the complex and is regulated by The [[Puerto Rican Football Federation]]. Field 1 is home to [[Puerto Rico Bayamon]], a member of the [[Liga Puerto Rico]] and previously the [[Puerto Rico Soccer League]]. ==Fields== ===Bayamon Soccer Complex I=== Fields 1 & 2 is centrally located serving multiple neighborhoods in the city of Bayamon; being Minillas, Tio, Reparto Zarina, and Vista Bella. Being a couple miles to the south of Bayamon Soccer Complex 2. The field 1 is a professional sized soccer field and field 2 is a recreational sized soccer field with a small youth sized field for youth teams attached to the west. ===Bayamon Soccer Complex II=== [[File:Bayamon Soccer Complex II sign.jpg|thumb|Bayamon Soccer Complex II or known as Parque de Futbol Honda.]] Field 3 is also known by ''Parque de Futbol Honda'' by the community or ''Honda Soccer Park'' in English it is located in the Rio Hondo neighborhood of Bayamon. The field is a professional sized soccer field with a small youth sized field for youth teams attached to the west and tennis courts to the east. On March 9, 2016, [[Meredith College]] and [[State University of New York at Oneonta|SUNY Oneonta]] as a NCAA Division II women's lacrosse match-up. SUNY won the game 17–13.http://www.municipiodebayamon.com/lacrosse-en-bayamon-soccer-complex-2/ ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{DEFAULTSORT:Bayamón Soccer Complex}} [[Category:Bayamón FC]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Bayamón, Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Football venues in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:2011 establishments in Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]]

{{Infobox award | name = Best Record-Breaking Performance ESPY Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = best record-breaking performance | presenter = ESPN | country = | location = Los Angeles (2017) | year = 2001 | year2 = | holder = [[Roger Federer]] (USA) | website = {{URL|http://www.espn.co.uk/espys/}} }} The '''Best Record-Breaking Performance ESPY Award''' has been presented since 2001 to the [[amateur sports|amateur]] or [[professional sports|professional]] sportsperson, irrespective of nationality or sport contested, adjudged to have, in a single play, game, or season, completed the best record-breaking (and -setting) performance, irrespective of the nature of the record broken. Between 2001 and 2004, the award voting panel comprised variously fans; sportswriters and broadcasters, sports executives, and retired sportspersons, termed collectively ''experts''; and [[List of ESPN personalities|ESPN personalities]], but balloting thereafter has been undertaken exclusively by fans over the Internet from amongst choices nominated by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee. Through the 2001 iteration of the ESPY Awards, ceremonies were conducted in February of each year to honor achievements over the previous calendar year; awards presented thereafter are conferred in June and reflect performance from the June previous.Because of the [[ESPY Awards#Timing|rescheduling]] of the ESPY Awards ceremony, the award presented in 2002 was given in consideration of performance betwixt February 2001 and June 2002. ==List of winners== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |- !scope="col" |Year of award !scope="col" class="unsortable" |Image !scope="col" |Athlete !scope="col" |Nation of citizenship !scope="col" |Team !scope="col" |Competition, governing body, or league !scope="col" |Sport !scope="col" class="unsortable" |Record set !scope="col" |Previous record-holder !scope="col" class="unsortable" |Ref(s) |- |[[2001 in sports|2001]] |[[File:Pete Sampras.jpg|100px|alt=Pete Sampras in 1992]] !scope="row"| {{sortname|Pete|Sampras}} |{{USA}} |{{n/a}} |[[ATP Tour]] |[[Tennis]] |Total career [[Tennis terminology#S|men's singles]] [[Grand Slam title#Men's or women's singles|Grand Slam title]]s (13). revision.text:
{{infobox Museum |name = '''Canadian Ski Museum''' |image = |established = 1975 |location = |type = sport museum |director = Ivo Krupka |curator = |visitors = |website = [http://www.skimuseum.ca/ www.skimuseum.ca] }} The '''Canadian Ski Museum''' (French: ''Le Musée canadien du ski'') is a [[museum]] based in [[Mont-Tremblant, Quebec]]. It was founded in 1971 by a dedicated group of volunteers and [[ski]] enthusiasts. Shortly thereafter, in 1975 the museum was incorporated. Since 2011 it has left the [[Ottawa]] location with collection online or stored.
The museum's founders recognized the rapid expansion and development of the sport of [[skiing]] over the years; this inspired them to collect not only the material and artifacts related to skiing, but also the various stories associated with the early years. These artifacts and stories remain to be the foundation from which the museum has built its world-class collection.
Upon the museum's opening, Herman 'Jackrabbit' Smith-Johannsen [http://www.skimuseum.ca/biodata.php?lang=en&id=123] acted as the Patron of the Canadian Ski Museum, and donated several of his prize possessions to the collection. Within the museum exhibit is an area devoted to 'Jackrabbit', the protagonist and practitioner of cross country and wilderness skiing who lived and breathed skiing for 111 years of his legendary life.
The Canadian Ski Museum's unparalleled collection of artifacts and archival holdings are a priceless part of Canadian [[cultural heritage]]. Since the Museum's beginnings, the collection has continued to grow, and the presentations of displays and stories about the history of skiing in Canada have increased. The museum has an incredible collection of photographs, memorabilia, skis, poles and ski clothing donated by skiers, all devoted to preserving the memory of Canada's skiing past.
At present, volunteers supported by a small paid staff, carry out the Museum's activities. The Museum relies on the support of friends and donors to continue to preserve and present Canadian Ski Heritage.
The Canadian Ski Museum established the [[Canadian Ski Hall of Fame]] in 1982 [http://www.skimuseum.ca/famealpha.php?lang=en]. Since the creation of the Canadian Ski Hall of Fame over 140 people have been inducted. The Canadian Ski Hall of Fame honours the pioneers, competitors, builders and industry personnel that have contributed significantly to Canada's skiing/snowboarding heritage.
The Canadian Ski Museum is a registered Canadian Charity and governed by a Board of Directors, operating through the Chair of the Board and an Executive Committee. The Canadian Ski Museum is recognized by the Fédération Internationale de Ski ("FIS") the [[International Ski Federation]].
== Sources == * Virtual Museum of Canada [https://archive.is/20130115201356/http://www.virtualmuseum.ca/CommunityMemories/ACUS/000a/Exhibits/English/index.html] * Pacific Rim Snow Sports Alliance [http://www.pacificrimalliance.org/F.PublicAffairs/SkiHistory/museums.html] * Canadian Museum of Civilization [http://www.civilization.ca/hist/biography/biographi243e.html] * International Skiing Heritage Association [http://skiinghistory.org/]

{{use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = CHI | NOCname = [[Chilean Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1912 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.coch.cl }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Stockholm]] | competitors = 14 | sports = 4 | flagbearer = [[Leopoldo Palma]] | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }} [[Image:1912 Opening ceremony - Chile.JPG|thumb|350px|The team of Chile at the opening ceremony.]] '''[[Chile]]''' competed at the '''[[1912 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. It was the first official appearance of the nation at the modern [[Olympic Games]], although some sources claim that a single Chilean athlete competed at the [[1896 Summer Olympics]]. Fourteen competitors, all men, took part in sixteen events in four sports.{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/CHI/summer/1912/ |title=Chile at the 1912 Stockholm Summer Games |accessdate=8 November 2014 |work=sports-reference.com}} ==Athletics== {{main|Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics}} 6 athletes represented Chile. Ranks given are within that athlete's heat for running events. {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Athlete !rowspan="2"|Events !colspan="2"|Heat !colspan="2"|Semifinal !colspan="2"|Final |- !Result !Rank !Result !Rank !Result !Rank |- |rowspan=3| [[Pablo Eitel]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 100 metres|100 m]] |align=center| ? |align=center| 6 |align=center colspan=4| Did not advance |- |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 200 metres|200 m]] |align=center| ? |align=center| 5 |align=center colspan=4| Did not advance |- |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 110 metres hurdles|110 m hurdles]] |align=center| 17.2 |align=center| 1 |align=center| ? |align=center| 4 |align=center colspan=2| Did not advance |- |rowspan=2| [[Rodolfo Hammersley]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's high jump|High jump]] |align=center colspan=2| N/A |align=center| 1.60 |align=center| 28 |align=center colspan=2| Did not advance |- |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's standing high jump|Standing high jump]] |align=center colspan=2| N/A |align=center| 1.40 |align=center| 13 |align=center colspan=2| Did not advance |- | [[Federico Mueller]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 800 metres|800 m]] |align=center| ? |align=center| 5-7 |align=center colspan=4| Did not advance |- | [[Leopoldo Palma]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 800 metres|800 m]] |align=center| ? |align=center| 4 |align=center colspan=4| Did not advance |- | [[Rolando Salinas]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 10 kilometres walk|10 km walk]] |align=center| 55:02 |align=center| 7 |align=center colspan=4| Did not advance |- |rowspan=3| [[Alfonso Sánchez (athlete)|Alfonso Sánchez]] |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|5000 m]] |align=center colspan=2| N/A |align=center colspan=2| Did not finish |align=center colspan=2| Did not advance |- |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's 10,000 metres|10000 m]] |align=center colspan=2| N/A |align=center colspan=2| Did not finish |align=center colspan=2| Did not advance |- |[[Athletics at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's marathon|Marathon]] |align=center colspan=4| N/A |align=center colspan=2| Did not start |} ==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1912 Summer Olympics}} Four cyclists represented Chile. It was the first appearance of the nation in cycling. [[Alberto Downey]] had the best time in the time trial, the only race held, placing 42nd. The team of four had a combined time that placed them 9th of the 15 teams. ===Road cycling=== {|class=wikitable style="font-size:90%" |- !rowspan="2"|Cyclist !rowspan="2"|Events !colspan="2"|Final |- !Result !Rank |- | [[Alberto Downey]] |[[Cycling at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's individual time trial|Ind. time trial]] |align=center| 11:53:02.5 |align=center| 42 |- | [[Arturo Friedemann]] |[[Cycling at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's individual time trial|Ind. time trial]] |align=center| 12:28:20.8 |align=center| 67 |- | [[Cárlos Koller]] |[[Cycling at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's individual time trial|Ind. time trial]] |align=center| 12:13:49.2 |align=center| 58 |- | [[José Torres (cyclist)|José Torres]] |[[Cycling at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's individual time trial|Ind. time trial]] |align=center| 12:39:39.5 |align=center| 74 |- | Alberto Downey

{{refimprove|date=April 2008}} [[Image:Valkyrie (The Roaches).jpg|thumb|150px|Climbers on "Valkyrie" at [[the Roaches]], [[UK]]]] '''Climbing, or alpine, clubs''' form to promote and preserve the climbing way of life, including [[rock climbing]], [[ice climbing]], [[alpinism]] & [[ski mountaineering]].
Clubs frequently act as advocates to protect climbing areas, advocate for climbers around the world, preserve climbing’s history and chronicle climbing achievement.<ref>[http://americanalpineclub.org/ The purpose of the American Alpine Club]</ref>
Climbing clubs usually schedule climbing meets & events allowing members an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals, learn new skills and partake in [[lead climbing]] which by definition requires two or more individuals.
==Organization==
Climbing clubs are often affiliated to a [[Sport governing body|national governing or representative body]] for purposes of [[Liability insurance|public liability insurance]].
In the UK this is most often the [[British Mountaineering Council]]. In Ireland this is most often Mountaineering Ireland, [http://www.mountaineering.ie]
==Club facilities==
Clubs ''may'' typically provide:
* Scheduled meets & training * Mountain huts & reciprocal arrangements with other hut owners * Books, newsletters & other publications * Social events * Limited public/civil liability insurance * Rescue insurance * Discount schemes with climbing shops * Libraries & photo collections * Climbing grants * Conservation, stewardship & advocacy
==Notable climbing clubs== *[[Climbers' Club]] *[[California Mountaineering Group]] *[http://americanalpineclub.org/ American Alpine Club] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090313045558/http://www.alpine-club.org.uk/index.html British Alpine Club] *[http://www.sac-cas.ch/index.php?id=1&L=3 Swiss Alpine Club (Club Alpin Suisse)] *[http://www.ffcam.fr/ French Climbing Club (Club Alpin Francais)] *[[German Alpine Club]] *[http://nkbv.nl/ ( Netherlands glimbing and mountaineering society)]
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Maillotjaune.jpg|right|thumb|Commercial version of the yellow jersey, 2004]] A '''cycling jersey''' is a specialized [[Jersey (clothing)|jersey]] for [[cycling]]. While the vast majority of cyclists worldwide wear conventional clothing while riding, a jersey offers certain advantages for the sport-oriented cyclist. A cycling jersey is cut long in the back to accommodate the bent-over position used in sport-oriented cycling. Any pockets on the jersey are placed on the back panel as front pockets would tend to spill. The [[zipper]] is often made very long so that the cyclist can open up the jersey to allow for ventilation. The cycling jersey is usually worn with a tight fit in order to reduce air resistance. Jerseys are made from a material designed to wick moisture from the skin, keeping the cyclist cooler and more comfortable. Professional cycling is heavily [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]]ed; the traditional cycling jersey is printed with the [[logo]]s of a few of the [[cycling team]]'s sponsors. ==Origin== Jerseys symbolising race positions include the [[yellow jersey]], or ''maillot jaune'', from the [[Tour de France]], the [[maglia rosa|pink jersey]], or ''maglia rosa'', from the [[Giro d'Italia]], and the red jersey, or ''la roja,'' from the Vuelta de Espana. The first two jerseys were given the same color as the paper their original main [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsor]]s (both sports newspapers) were printed on: yellow and pink paper, respectively. The overall leader at the Vuelta at present wears a red jersey, although previously it has been the "maillot amarillo" (yellow jersey) and the "jersey de oro" (golden jersey). Many other jerseys are colored or designed after a sponsor's logo, and some jerseys change color when a new sponsor is found. ==Overview of jerseys== ===Grand Tour races=== {| class="wikitable" ! scope="col" width=185 | Course !! scope="col" | !! scope="col" | General leader !! scope="col" | Points leader !! scope="col" | Mountain leader !! scope="col" | Youth leader !! scope="col" | Other |- ! {{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[Giro d'Italia]]''' !! rowspan="3" | |[[Image:Jersey pink.svg|40px]] [[General classification in the Giro d'Italia|Pink jersey]]

revision.text:
{{citations missing|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox_Stadium | stadium_name = Doha Stadium
אצטדיון דוחא | nickname = Peace Stadium | image = [[File:Doha Stadium01.jpg|250px|center]] | location = [[Sakhnin]], [[Israel]] | broke_ground = 2004 | opened = 2006 | owner = [[Sakhnin|Town of Sakhnin]] | operator = Town of Sakhnin | surface = Grass | construction_cost = US $15,000,000 | architect = | tenants = [[Bnei Sakhnin F.C.|Bnei Sakhnin]] (2006-present)
[[Ahva Arraba F.C.|Ahva Arraba]]
[[Bnot Sakhnin F.C.|Bnot Sakhnin]] | seating_capacity = 8,500 }} '''Doha Stadium''' ({{lang-he|אצטדיון דוחא}}, ''Etztadion Doha''; {{lang-ar|ستاد دوحة}}) is the current home of [[Bnei Sakhnin F.C.|Bnei Sakhnin]]. Located in the [[Israeli Arab]] [[Galilee]] city of [[Sakhnin]], it was built with public funds largely from the [[State of Israel]] and the [[Qatar Olympic Committee|Qatar National Olympic Committee]], and was named after the Qatari city of [[Doha]]. The decision by the Qataris to build the stadium in Israel came after a meeting between the [[Knesset]] member [[Ahmad Tibi]] and Secretary-General of the Qatar National Olympic Committee Sheikh [[Saud Abdulrahman Al Thani]] after Tibi expressed his concern on the conditions for sport in Sakhnin. The involvement of Qatar was to show that relations between the two nations are peaceful and with a similar interest.{{cite news |first=Ro'ei |last=Nahmias |title=Why "Doha" Stadium and not "HaShalom"? |url=http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/1,7340,L-3200229,00.html |publisher=[[Yedioth Ahronoth]] |id= |pages= |page= |date=2006-01-14 |accessdate=2007-10-08 |language=Hebrew}} In July 2009, the north stand was opened with additional of 3,500 seats.{{cite news |title=The construction of the Doha stadium's north stand was completed |url=http://one.co.il/Msites/Biz/InsideArticle.aspx?id=141388&bz=6 |publisher=One.co.il |id= |pages= |page= |date=2009-07-27 |accessdate=2009-07-27 |language=Hebrew}} There are plans to expand the stadium's capacity to 15,000. ==Footnotes== {{reflist}} {{coord|32|52|00.09|N|35|18|39.06|E|type:landmark|display=title}} {{Israeli Premier League}} [[Category:Football venues in Israel]] [[Category:Bnei Sakhnin F.C.]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2006]] [[Category:Sports venues in Northern District (Israel)]]

{{Football club infobox | clubname = Evolucas | image = | fullname = Evolucas | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Stade Jean Naffer]],
[[Petit-Bourg]], [[Guadeloupe]] | capacity = | chairman = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Vincent Gaétan Vilnard]] | manager = {{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Alex Parnasse]]
{{flagicon|Guadeloupe|local}} [[Mario Kancel]] | league = [[Guadeloupe Championnat National]] | season = 2007/08 | position = Champions | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FF0000|body1=FF0000|rightarm1=FF0000|shorts1=FF0000|socks1=FF0000 }} '''Evolucas''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club in [[Guadeloupe]], based in the town of [[Petit-Bourg]]. They play in Guadeloupe's first division, the [[Guadeloupe Championnat National]] and claimed their first domestic league title in the 2007/2008 season. ==Achievements== *'''[[Guadeloupe Championnat National]]: 1''' :: 2008 ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090109162345/http://foot2gwada.blogs.francefootball.com/effectifs_des_clubs_de_dh/ Tour des clubs 2008–2009] – Gwadafoot {{fr icon}} * [http://www.fff.fr/competitions/php/club/club_fiche.php?cl_no=7010 Club info] – French Football Federation {{fr icon}} {{Guadeloupe Division d’Honneur}} [[Category:Football clubs in Guadeloupe]] {{Guadeloupe-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Drita | image = KF Drita.svg | image_size = 175px | fullname = Football Club Drita | nickname = {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Intelektualët}} (Intellectuals)}} | short name = DFC | founded = {{Start date and years ago|1947|df=y}} | ground = [[Gjilan City Stadium]] | capacity = 15,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = Valon Murseli | mgrtitle = Manager | manager = [[Shpëtim Duro]] | league = [[Football Superleague of Kosovo]] | season = [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo|2017–18]] | position = Football Superleague of Kosovo, 1st | website = http://www.dritafc.com/ | pattern_la1 = _whitelines | pattern_b1 = _Drita2018 | pattern_ra1 = _whitelines | pattern_sh1 = _white stripes | pattern_so1 = _bluetop | leftarm1 = 000080 | body1 = 000080 | rightarm1 = 000080 | shorts1 = 000080 | socks1 = | pattern_la2 = _bluelines | pattern_b2 = _DritaAwayKit2018-2019 | pattern_ra2 = _bluelines | pattern_sh2 = _white stripes | pattern_so2 = _bluetop | leftarm2 = FFFFFF | body2 = FFFFFF | rightarm2 = FFFFFF | shorts2 = 000080 | socks2 = | pattern_la3 = _bluelines | pattern_b3 = _DritaThirdKit | pattern_ra3 = _bluelines | pattern_sh3 = _white stripes | pattern_so3 = _bluetop | leftarm3 = 363636 | body3 = FFFFFF | rightarm3 = 363636 | shorts3 = 06bae8 | socks3 = 363636 | current = 2018–19 FC Drita season }} {{FC Drita sections}} '''Football Club Drita''' ({{lang-sq|Klubi Futbollistik Drita}}), commonly known as '''Drita''' is a professional [[Football team|football club]] based in [[Gjilan]], [[Kosovo]]. The club play in the [[Football Superleague of Kosovo]], which is the top tier of football in the country. ==History== In 1947, Drita was founded by the Gjilan citizens, the name Drita means [[light]] in [[Albanian language]] and the name was taken from other sports clubs from the city. The first club footballers trained under extraordinary circumstances and in difficult conditions, without food, just to succeed. They testified their talent with their inescapable will. From the beginning it was a snag of the communist government because it rivaled the other team of the city, their favorite, [[SC Gjilani|Crvena Zvezda Gnjilane]] and because the founders and footballers were only [[Albanians]] and had an Albanian name. Therefore, in 1952 the team is extinguished by the regime. Former footballers went to the already multi-ethnic team of Zvezda, but the team didn't completely get erased. They competed in the [[Football Superleague of Kosovo|Kosovo Province League]] where they were declared champions in the 1962–63 season.{{cite web|url=http://www.dritafc.com/about.html|title=Historia e FC Drita|trans-title=History of FC Drita|language=Albanian|publisher=FC Drita}}. ===Post-1990=== [[File:BekimIsufi (cropped).jpg|thumb|250px|[[Bekim Isufi]] was the most successful coach of Drita during Valon Murseli and Flamur Bunjaku era, he won [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo]], [[2018 Kosovar Supercup]] and assured Drita participation at European competitions.]] In 1991. At the time of the dissolution of [[Yugoslavia]]. the football of Kosovo was in its zenith and consistently had 4-5 clubs in both federal leagues. But the deterioration of the political situation was also reflected in sports. In 1991, Albanian separatist complaining about the situation, formed the [[Football Federation of Kosovo]] with all its organs. Drita then joined the new league system in [[Kosovo]], where they played in the fields of the mountains around the city of [[Gjilan]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ffk-kosova.com/federata/hostoriku/|title=Historiku|trans-title=History|publisher=[[Football Federation of Kosovo]]|accessdate=2 October 2018}} ===Selami Osmani era=== After the 90s, Drita was taken into management by Selami Osmani - Bezi with whom for 15 years reached the tops of Kosovan football, thanks to the players that brought in Gjilan, he who for 15 years contributed to Drita. Under his management Drita managed to adorn the title of the [[Football Superleague of Kosovo|Kosovo championship]] in 2002–03, win the cup in 2000–01 and be a runner-up in 1999–2000 and 2001–02. Drita also reached the semifinals in 1999–00, 2001–02 and 2002–03, breaking a Kosovo record that for four consecutive years did not descend below the third position and for four years at least until the semifinals of the [[Kosovar Cup]].{{cite news|url=http://dritafc.com/rreth-nesh.html|title=Rreth nesh|trans-title=About us|language=Albanian|publisher=FC Drita}} ===Valon Murseli and Flamur Bunjaku era=== On 21 July 2016, Valon Murseli and Flamur Bunjaku took over the club, the two businessmans promised big things to the club, where in [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo|2017–18]] they relied on them, proclaiming champions for the second time in the clubs history.{{cite news|url=https://rajonipress.com/valon-murseli-e-flamur-bunjaku-premtojne-drita-do-te-shkelqej/|title=Valon Murseli e Flamur Bunjaku premtojnë Drita do të shkëlqej|trans-title=Valon Murseli and Flamur Bunjaku promise the Drita will shine|language=Albanian|website=RajoniPress|date=21 July 2016}} ==Support== {{main|Intelektualët}} {{Infobox sport supporter group |name = Intelektualët |founded = {{Start date and years ago|1998|df=y}} |motto = No one likes us, we don't care |type = [[Ultras]] group |team = All clubs with name '''Drita''' from [[Gjilan]] |colors = {{Color box|Blue|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|White|border=darkgray}}{{Color box|Black|border=darkgray}} |location = [[Gjilan]], {{nowrap|{{flag|Kosovo}}}} |affiliations = ''BKHooligans, Bojanina Blue Boys, Brigada 138, DH-B Hools, E7 Hools, Hienat, PM Mahalla, Q.Q Hools, ULH and GC Hools'' |arena = [[Gjilan City Stadium]] }} Drita in the 1997–98 championship was great wherever in Kosovo and in many sporting games, the meetings started but it was difficult to name the fans. The [[KF Ballkani|Ballkani]] and Drita match was a tough game because Ballkani fought for the survival and Drita for champion, so the fans traveled to [[Suva Reka]] for the last time without a name after this game, before the game against biggest rival Gjilani, the board succumbed and after many debates the name {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Intelektualët}} (Intellectuals)}} was assigned because most of the players except they played were also writers, poets, politicians and so on.{{cite web|url=http://tifozat.com/viewpage.php?page_id=11|title=Intelektualët|trans-title=Intellectuals|website=Tifozat}} The Intellectuals are the biggest [[Ultras|ultras]] group in Kosovo, with many transfers outside Gjilan. They also have the record of audience in football of Kosovo, the biggest was against Gjilani in 2011 with 13,000 fans and they traveled also in 2002 with 30,000 fans to the final of the [[Kosovar Cup]] in the [[Fadil Vokrri Stadium]]. ===Incidents=== Also at {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Intelektualet}} (Intellectuals)}} there are groups of hooligans who do incidents especially during the derby towards [[SC Gjilani|Gjilani]].{{cite news|url=https://archive.koha.net/?id=&l=71877|title=Rrahja ndërmjet tifozëve në derbin Drita-Gjilani [video]|trans-title=Beating between fans in derby Drita-Gjilani [video|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Koha Ditore]]|date=23 August 2015}} But there are also other incidents with other groups, The incident with {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Plisat}}}} of [[FC Prishtina|Prishtina]] was where during the last game of the championship there was attack on the fans of Prishtina, the worst incident was the violation of the fans of Prishtina by the hooligans from Gjilan where 13 fans were injured.{{cite news|url=http://zeri.info/sport/199620/momenti-kur-makina-e-intelektualeve-shkele-qellimisht-plisat-dhe-perleshja-mes-tifozeve/|title=Momenti kur makina e Intelektualëve shkelë qëllimisht Plisat dhe përleshja mes tifozëve|trans-title=The moment when the car of Intellectual intentionally violates the Plisat and the clash between the fans|language=Albanian|website=Zeri|accessdate=19 July 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://indeksonline.net/vetura-me-tabela-te-gjilanit-godet-tifozet-e-prishtines-ne-peje-video-foto/|title=Vetura me tabela të Gjilanit godet tifozët e Prishtinës në Pejë|trans-title=The car with vehicle plates of Gjilan strikes Pristina fans in Peja|language=Albanian|website=Indeksonline|accessdate=19 July 2018}} ==Club rivalries== [[File:The Kosovo Derby at Gjilan City Stadium in 2018.jpg|thumb|250px|The [[Kosovo Derby]] at [[Gjilan City Stadium]] in 30 September 2018]] ===Gjilani=== {{see also|Kosovo Derby}} There is often a fierce rivalry between the two strongest teams in a national league and this is particularly the case in the Football Superleague of Kosovo, where the game between Drita and [[SC Gjilani|Gjilani]] is known as the [[Kosovo Derby]]. According to the tradition of the city of Gjilan, the party starts with fans organization, who try to give the maximum support for the respective clubs, there is also some surprise for the other opponent camp, to say that we were better and is appreciated more than what is presented to you with great curiosity about the whole city, what a presentation will be on the weekend from {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Skifterat}} (Falcons)}} and {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Intelektualët}} (Intellectuals)}}. Three days before the match the derby gives the atmosphere a night life, everywhere in the cafe bars is an atmosphere that occurs only during national holidays, where fans are seen by both the {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Skifterat}} (Falcons)}} and {{nowrap|{{lang|sq|Intelektualët}} (Intellectuals)}} to live all that week under the fever of the much-anticipated derby. One hour before the match, the two camps are organized in groups and always avoid eventual incidents between the two ultras groups. They divide the streets from where they will go to the stadium, which is good, because the [[Kosovo Police]] organised themselves in a way to avoid the breakdown of this holiday and the much anticipated confrontation in Gjilan. For a brief few moments, everything apart from the dozens of flares that littered the pitch, that'd had disappeared from view. Gone were the two white minarets that usually overlook the stadium in eastern Kosovo. Gone too were the lines of riot police patrolling the front of the main stand along with the 10,000 strong crowd, all enveloped in a monstrous blue cloud of smoke. On the other side of the pitch, a similar scene was being played out, but the consuming cloud was red. The only evidence of a football match being played was the thunderous noise of drums and chants rising ethereally from the fog.{{cite web|title=Kosovo: new nation, fresh problems|url=http://www.worldsoccer.com/features/kosovo-new-nation-fresh-problems-390837#jzZlcKyWupdVDG3g.99|website=Worldsoccer.com|publisher=James Montague|accessdate=20 November 2016}} ==Records and statistics== Drita in the [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo|2017–18 season]] has not suffered any losses, so it has broken its record since 2002–03 season with 30 undefeated games.{{cite news|url=http://www.ffk-kosova.com/federata/2018/05/20/drita-feston-titullin-e-dyte-te-kampionit-ne-histori/|title=Drita feston titullin e kampionit, të dytin në histori|trans-title=Drita celebrates the title of the champion, the second in history|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Football Federation of Kosovo]]|date=20 May 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.arbresh.info/sport/historike-drita-e-bekim-isufit-kampione-pa-asnje-humbje/|title=Historike: Drita e Bekim Isufit, kampione pa asnjë humbje|trans-title=Historical: Drita of Bekim Isufi, champion without any loss|language=Albanian|website=Arbresh.info|date=20 May 2018}} {| class="wikitable" |- !Accomplishment !Record !{{Abbr|Ref|Reference}} |- !colspan="3"|Players |- |Most matches |{{flagicon|KVX}} [[Artan Latifi]] with 246 caps |rowspan="2" style="text-align:center"|{{cite news|url=http://futbollikosovar.com/ja-futbollisti-me-me-se-shumti-paraqitje-te-drita-si-dhe-top-shenuesi-me-i-mire-i-gjitha-kohrave/22779/superliga/|title=Ja futbollisti me më së shumti paraqitje te Drita si dhe top-shenuesi më i mirë i gjitha kohrave?!|trans-title=Here is the player with the most appearance to Drita as well as the top goalscorer of all times?!|language=Albanian|website=Futbolli Kosovar|date=11 August 2018}} |- |Most goals |{{flagicon|KVX}} [[Xhevdet Shabani]] with 113 goals |- !colspan="3"|Team records |- |Biggest ever European victory |1–4 away against {{flagicon|GIB}} [[Lincoln Red Imps F.C.]],
29 June 2018 |style="text-align:center"|{{cite news|url=http://www.balkanweb.com/site/video-drita-shkruan-historine-mund-linkolnin-dhe-kalon-ne-raundin-tjeter-kualifikues/|title=VIDEO/Drita shkruan historinë mund Linkolnin dhe kalon në raundin tjetër kualifikues|trans-title=VIDEO/Drita writes the history can Lincoln and passes to the next qualifying round|language=Albanian|website=BalkanWeb|date=30 June 2018}} |- |rowspan="2"|Biggest ever European defeat |0–3 home against {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Malmö FF|Malmö]], 10 July 2018 |style="text-align:center"|{{cite news|url=https://kallxo.com/drita-humb-ndeshjen-e-pare-ndaj-malmos/|title=Drita humb ndeshjen e parë ndaj Malmos|trans-title=Drita loses the first match against Malmo|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Kallxo]]|date=10 July 2018}} |- |2–0 away against {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Malmö FF|Malmö]], 17 July 2018 |style="text-align:center"|{{cite news|url=http://newsport.al/drita-eleminohet-nga-europa-kampionet-kosovar-japin-lajmin-e-madh-per-tifozet/|title=Drita eleminohet nga Europa? Kampionët kosovar japin lajmin e madh për tifozët|trans-title=Drita is eliminated from Europe? Kosovan champions give great news for fans|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Kallxo]]|date=10 July 2018}} |- |Longest unbeaten run at all competitions |31 games in [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo|2017–18 season]] |rowspan="2" style="text-align:center"| |- |Longest unbeaten run at [[Football Superleague of Kosovo]] |29 games in [[2017–18 Football Superleague of Kosovo|2017–18 season]]
30 games in [[Football Superleague of Kosovo]] between 2 seasons |} ==Kit evolution== After the war, the financial condition of clubs did not allow them to look after their kits, it happened that within a season the club's shirts have changed. But since joining [[UEFA]] and [[FIFA]], this problem has disappeared. During the presentation of Betim Haxhimusa, they also unveiled the new kits that would be worn in the 2018–19 season, while the traditional colors are interwoven in a design inspired by the famous sportswear brand [[Givova]].{{cite news|url=http://gazetaolle.com/keto-jane-fanellat-e-drites-per-edicionin-e-ardhshem/|title=Këto janë fanellat e Dritës për edicionin e ardhshëm|trans-title=These are the kits of Drita for the upcoming edition|language=Albanian|website=GazetaOlle|accessdate=22 July 2018}} While in the UEFA Champions League match against [[Malmö FF|Malmö]] in [[Sweden]], Drita played with their third kits making the presentation in public for the first time. ===Period=== {| |valign="top"| {|width=60% border=1 cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="background: #FFF; The stadium has a capacity of 10,000 people all seater. Since 2017, the stadium is under renovation as it does not meet any level required by UEFA and the goal is to get the stadium to become a [[UEFA stadium categories|fourth-tier UEFA stadium]].{{cite news|url=https://www.koha.net/sport/56459/nis-ndertimi-i-stadiumit-ne-gjilan/|title=Nis ndërtimi i stadiumit në Gjilan|trans-title=Stadium construction begins in Gjilan|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Koha Ditore]]|accessdate=22 July 2018}} ==Honours== [[File:DritaSuperCup2018.jpg|thumb|300px|Drita celebrating their [[2018 Kosovar Supercup]] win against [[FC Kosovan Superleague|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Ora News]]|date=17 September 2018}} {{div col end}} ==Drita in Europe== Drita competed in the [[UEFA Champions League]] for the first time in the [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League|2018–19 season]], entering at the [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League qualifying phase and play-offs (Champions Path)#Preliminary round|preliminary round]]. On 12 June 2018, in [[Nyon]], the draw was held and Drita were drawn against the Andorran side [[FC Santa Coloma|Santa Coloma]].{{cite news|url=http://www.gazetaexpress.com/sport/zyrtare-ky-eshte-kundershtari-i-drites-ne-rundin-preliminar-per-champions-547187/|title=Zyrtare: Ky është kundërshtari i Dritës në rundin preliminar për Champions|trans-title=Official: This is the opponent of Drita in preliminary round for Champions|quote=Kampioni i Kosovës, Drita e ka mësuar kundërshtarin për rundin preliminar në Ligën e Kampionëve. Drita do të përballet me kampionin e Andorrës, FC Santa Coloma (AND), raporton Gazeta Express|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Gazeta Express]]|date=12 June 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.panorama.com.al/sport/hidhet-shorti-per-ligen-e-kampioneve-drita-njeh-kundershtarin/|title=Hidhet shorti për Ligën e Kampionëve, Drita njeh kundërshtarin|trans-title=The draw for the Champions League. Drita knows the opponent|quote=Skuadra kampione e Kosovës, Drita ka mësuar kundërshtarin e saj në Ligën e Kampionëve, turni paraeleminator. Në total ishin 4 skuadra që merrnin pjese. Shorti i ka vendosur përballë skuadrën nga Andorra, Santa Coloma|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Panorama Sport]]|date=12 June 2018}} On 26 June 2018, Drita beat Santa Coloma at [[Victoria Stadium (Gibraltar)|Victoria Stadium]] in [[Gibraltar]] and became the first Kosovar side to win a [[UEFA Champions League]] match.{{cite news|url=http://www.gazetaexpress.com/sport/drita-histor-fiton-ndeshjen-e-pare-ne-ligen-e-kampioneve-552538/|title=Drita historike, fiton ndeshjen e parë në Ligën e Kampionëve|trans-title=Historic Drita, wins the first match in Champions League|quote=Kjo është fitorja e parë e një ekipi kosovar në Ligën e Kampionëve|language=Albanian|publisher=[[Gazeta Express]]|date=26 June 2018}} After being eliminated from [[Malmö FF|Malmö]], Drita continued to play in the [[2018–19 UEFA Europa League qualifying phase and play-offs (Champions Path)#Second qualifying round|second qualifying round]] of [[UEFA Europa League]]. On 17 July 2018, Drita learns the upcoming rival which was the champion of [[2017–18 Luxembourg National Division]], [[F91 Dudelange]].{{cite news|url=http://www.arbresh.info/sport/drita-meson-rivalin-e-ardhshem-ne-arenen-nderkombetare1/|title=Drita mëson rivalin e ardhshëm në arenën ndërkombëtare|trans-title=Drita learns the upcoming rival in the international arena|language=Albanian|website=Arbresh.info|date=17 July 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://topsporti.com/artikulli/drita-vazhdon-rrugen-ne-europa-league/ffk-superliga|title=Drita vazhdon rrugën në Europa League|trans-title=Drita continues the way in the Europa League|language=Albanian|website=TopSporti|date=18 July 2018}} {{football squad on pitch|align=right |GK_nat = KVX|GK = Rexhepi |RB_nat = KVX|RB = [[Viktor Kuka|Kuka]] |RCB_nat = KVX|RCB = Gërbeshi |LCB_nat = KVX|LCB = Limani ([[Captain (association football)|c]]) |LB_nat = KVX|LB = [[Liridon Leci|Leci]] |RM_nat = KVX|RM = Krasniqi |RCM_nat = KVX|RCM = [[Bujar Shabani|B. {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Fred Handler Park | nickname = | image = | fullname = Fred Handler Park at McGraw-Jennings Field | former_names = McGraw-Jennings Field (1958–2006) | location = College Street, [[St. Bonaventure, New York]], USA | coordinates = {{coord|42.079378|-78.486478|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = | renovated = 2006 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[St. Bonaventure University]] | operator = St. Bonaventure University | surface = Sport Turf XP | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = '''Left Field:''' {{convert|330|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Left Center Field:''' {{convert|367|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Center Field:''' {{convert|403|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Center Field:''' {{convert|367|ft|m|sp=us}}
'''Right Field:''' {{convert|330|ft|m|sp=us}} | acreage = | tenants = [[St. Bonaventure Bonnies baseball]]
([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|D1]] [[Atlantic 10 Conference|A-10]])
[[Olean Oilers]] ([[New York Collegiate Baseball League|NYCBL]]) (2012) }} '''Fred Handler Park at McGraw-Jennings Field''' is a baseball venue in [[St. Bonaventure, New York]], United States. It is home to the [[St. Bonaventure Bonnies baseball]] team of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Atlantic 10 Conference]].{{cite web|title=Fred Handler Park |url=http://www.gobonnies.com/inside_athletics/facilities/Fred-Handler-Park |work=Go Bonnies |publisher=St. Bonaventure University Athletic Department |accessdate=2 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65A3ToNIy?url=http://www.gobonnies.com/inside_athletics/facilities/Fred-Handler-Park |archivedate=2 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} == Naming == The field is named for [[John McGraw]] and [[Hugh Jennings]], who coached the baseball program from 1892 to 1895. Both McGraw and Jennings are members of the [[National Baseball Hall of Fame]].{{cite web|title=Baseball Hall of Fame Alphabetical List|url=http://www.baseball-almanac.com/hof/hofmem.shtml|work=Baseball Almanac|accessdate=2 February 2012|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20020522143435/http://www.baseball-almanac.com/hof/hofmem.shtml|archivedate=22 May 2002|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The park is named for [[Fred Handler]], St. Bonaventure head baseball coach from 1960 to 1981,{{cite web |title=Baseball Statistics |url=http://web.sbu.edu/friedsam/archives/athletics/baseball/statistics.htm |work=SBU.edu |accessdate=2 February 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65A3gyncA?url=http://web.sbu.edu/friedsam/archives/athletics/baseball/statistics.htm |archivedate=2 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} assistant basketball coach from 1960 to 1970, professor of [[physical education]] from 1959 to 1997, and member of the university's Athletics Hall of Fame. Previously known simply as '''McGraw-Jennings Field''', the venue's name was changed to its current one on 9 September 2006. == Renovations and features == In 2006, the field underwent extensive renovations due to the US$900,000 donation of trustee and former baseball player Thomas Marra. The renovations included new [[bullpen]]s, [[Dugout (baseball)|dugout]]s, fencing, and a Sport Turf XP surface. The field also features a [[press box]] and [[berm]] seating areas down both [[Glossary of baseball (F)#foul lines|foul line]]s. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Atlantic 10 Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{New York NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:St. Bonaventure Bonnies baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cattaraugus County, New York]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:1958 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1958]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Hearnes Center | nickname = | image = [[Image:HearnesCenter1.jpg|250px]] | location = 600 E Stadium Blvd
Columbia, MO 65211 | broke_ground = 1969 | opened = August 4, 1972 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Univ. of Missouri | operator = Univ. of Missouri | surface = | construction_cost = $10.75 million | architect = [[Sverdrup & Parcel]] | former_names = | tenants = [[Missouri Tigers]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]])
[[Missouri Tigers men's basketball|Men's basketball]] (1972–2004)
Wrestling (1972–present)
Track and field (fieldhouse annex) (1973–present)
[[Missouri Tigers women's basketball|Women's basketball]] (1974–2004)
Women's volleyball (1975–present)
Women's gymnastics (1979–present) | seating_capacity = 13,611 (1972-present) }} '''Hearnes Center''' is a 13,611-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Columbia, Missouri]]. The arena opened in 1972. It is currently home to the Missouri Tigers' [[Collegiate wrestling|wrestling]] and volleyball teams as well as the school's [[artistic gymnastics|gymnastics]] and indoor [[track & field]] teams. It was home to the [[University of Missouri]] Tigers [[basketball]] [[team]] before [[Mizzou Arena]] opened in 2004. Groundbreaking for the Hearnes Center occurred in 1969, and the arena was officially dedicated on August 4, 1972. The arena got its name from former Missouri governor and 1952 Mizzou graduate [[Warren Hearnes]]. The cost of the building project was $10.75 million. Prior to the opening of the Hearnes Center, the Missouri basketball team played its home games at [[Brewer Fieldhouse]], which was built in 1929 and has since been remodeled into a modern recreation center. Hearnes quickly became one of the toughest places to play during the 1980s, when players such as [[Steve Stipanovich]], [[Jon Sundvold]], [[Derrick Chievous]] and [[Doug Smith (basketball)|Doug Smith]] suited up for [[Norm Stewart]]. Several factors contributed to this reputation: the steep banking of the seating area, its flat roof and angling of its upper sections, and [[The Antlers (University of Missouri)|The Antlers]], whose presence in Section A-16 made them the bane of many an opposition. Decibel meters were added to the corners of the arena in the early 1990s in addition to new scoreboards, and it was not uncommon to see them go well above 110 dB during conference games, and regularly cresting 125 dB against [[Kansas Jayhawks basketball|Kansas]] or during 2001's famed "Fire Code Game" against [[2001–02 Iowa Hawkeyes men's basketball team|Iowa]], where well over 14,500 people packed the building to see then-#2 Mizzou be stunned by [[Steve Alford]]'s club. In its later life, the building saw several changes: a new floor was installed in 1998, rear-projection video monitors replaced the matrix boards at the turn of the new millennium, and the student seating plan was also altered. Before [[Quin Snyder]] came to coach the Tigers, student seating was scattered throughout the arena and distributed via who picked up tickets first, and while the largest amount sat along one sideline (including the band, Student Athletic Board and the aforementioned Antlers), others sat as high as the D sections, which early in the arena's life doubled as lecture halls (to this day, their seats have fold-out writing desks). Attempting to create an atmosphere similar to his former employers, [[Duke Blue Devils basketball|Duke]], Snyder mandated that all students be moved to one end of the court, where bleachers would replace the old seats and primacy would be given to his new "Zou Crew" club, with all other seating areas becoming general admission. The move was criticized for changing the atmosphere at Missouri games to something less distinctive while enabling more seats to be sold at a higher cost, but was duplicated (with more restrictions on student seating) at Mizzou Arena. The Hearnes Center also contains a field house that is home to the indoor track and field team, as well as one of the country's largest [[blood donation|blood drives]]. Each fall, students donate blood as part of the school's [[Homecoming]] week festivities. In 2005, students and [[Columbia, Missouri|Columbia]] residents donated over 5,000 units of blood. [[Image:HearnesCenter2.jpg|thumb|left|150px]]During the school year, the parking lot adjacent to the main building serves as student parking for the many on-campus residents. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Mizzou}} {{Missouri Tigers men's basketball navbox}} {{coord|38.93434|N|92.33060|W|source:placeopedia|display=title}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Missouri]] [[Category:College gymnastics venues in the United States]] [[Category:College indoor track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:College volleyball venues in the United States]] [[Category:College wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indoor track and field venues in the United States]] [[Category:Missouri Tigers basketball venues]] [[Category:Missouri Tigers track and field venues]] [[Category:Defunct college basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Columbia, Missouri]] [[Category:Sports venues in Missouri]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1972]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Columbia, Missouri]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Missouri]] [[Category:1972 establishments in Missouri]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox Sport governing body |assocname= Koninklijke Nederlandse Cricket Bond |abbrev = |logo= KNCB.gif |sport= [[Cricket]] |category = |image = |caption = |jurisdiction = [[Cricket in the Netherlands]] |founded = {{Start date|1883}} |aff = |affdate = |region = |regionyear = |headquarters = [[Nieuwegein]] |location = [[Nieuwegein]] |president = |chairman = |chiefexec = |secretary = |coach = [[Anton Roux]] |womenscoach = [[Ed de Moura Correia]] |key staff = |operating income = |sponsor = [[ABN AMRO]], [[Amul]], [[Canterbury of New Zealand|Canterbury]] |year closed = |replaced = |prevfounded = |url = www.kncb.nl/ |countryflag=Netherlands |countryflag2= }} The '''[[Koninklijk]]e Nederlandse Cricket Bond''' ('''KNCB'''; English: Royal Dutch Cricket Board) is the governing body of [[cricket]] in the [[Kingdom of the Netherlands]]. It was formed in 1883 and received a Royal charter in 1958. The KNCB is responsible for the [[Netherlands national cricket team|national men's]] and [[Netherlands national women's cricket team|women's team]]s, and also for the various domestic competitions, including the [[Topklasse (cricket)|Topklasse]] (Division One) and [[Hoofdklasse (cricket)|Hoofdklasse]] (Division Two) leagues, and the [[Dutch Twenty20 Cup|Twenty20 Cup]]. The KNCB has been an associate member of the [[International Cricket Council]] since 1966. It is one of the oldest national governing bodies in the sport, older than those of many full ICC members. The KNCB is also a member of the [[European Cricket Council]], which organises the [[European Cricket Championship]].
==Overview== Koninklijke Nederlandse Cricket Bond is an administrative organization responsible for the promotion, development, and organization of the sport of [[cricket]] in the Netherlands. It controls the [[Netherlands national cricket team|men's national team]], and the [[Netherlands national women's cricket team|women's national team]] teams. The women's national team currently have [[Test cricket|Test status]] and played their first Test match in 2007. A total of 57 cricket clubs take part in the domestic season, which include the Hoofdklasse, Topklasse and the region T20 cricket.<ref> [http://www.kncb.nl/index.php?option=com_chronoconnectivity&Itemid=423 Informatie Clubs] KNCB (''This page is in Dutch.'') Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
==History== Cricket was first seen being played on Dutch soil in the 1780s by an English traveller in Scheveningen, and by the turn of the 20th century, Dutch teams were touring England regularly. Cricket was one of the most popular sports in the Netherlands in the 19th century, surpassed since by many other sports, most notably association football. Cricket even found enough of a following to survive the German occupation of the country between May 1940 and May 1945. The sport, famously dismissed as "unmanly and un-German" and "insufficiently violent" by [[Adolf Hitler]] himself, endured thanks in no small part to the dogged enthusiasm of local players, who shrugged off the requisitioning of grounds and restrictions on weekend travel – not to mention the presence of thousands of heavily armed Nazis and the bombing of the main sports dealers in Rotterdam – to organise as many as 300 matches a year.<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/532591.html Eyeing the orange future] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
The KNCB has been an associate member of the [[International Cricket Council]] since 1966.<ref> [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Countries/20.html Netherlands Profile] CricketArchive. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> There are a few cricket grounds in the Netherlands which are officially sanctioned by the ICC to host ODIs such as [[Amsterdam]], [[Amstelveen]] and [[Voorburg]]. It hosted some of the matches of the [[1999 Cricket World Cup]], though the Dutch did not participate in that tournament.<ref> [http://static.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/WORLD_CUPS/WC99/ ICC Cricket World Cup 1999] Static Cricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
The Dutch participated in the [[1996 Cricket World Cup]], [[2003 Cricket World Cup]], [[2007 Cricket World Cup]], and [[2011 Cricket World Cup]]. In their debut campaign, they lost all of their matches barring a respectful performance against England. They qualified for the 2003 edition after winning the [[2001 ICC Trophy]],<ref> [http://static.cricinfo.com/db/ARCHIVE/WORLD_CUPS/ICCT2001/ ICC Trophy 2001] Static Cricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> with their only win of the World Cup tournament coming against fellow qualifier Namibia. It was around this time that stars and excellent cricketers like [[Ronald Lefebvre]] and [[Ryan ten Doeschate]] started emerging to make Dutch cricket much more strong.
===Present Day=== The Dutch qualified for the 2007 World Cup with a fifth-place finish at the [[2005 ICC Trophy]].<ref> [http://www.cricketeurope4.net/ICCT2005/home.shtml ICC Trophy 2005] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403144540/http://www.cricketeurope4.net/ICCT2005/home.shtml |date= 3 April 2007 }} CricketEurope (Official Website). Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> The Dutch had a poor tournament, losing all three of their games, with South African [[Herschelle Gibbs]] notably hitting [[Dan van Bunge]] for six [[Boundary_(cricket)#Scoring_runs|sixes]] in an over. After failing to qualify for the [[2007 ICC World Twenty20]], they qualified for the [[2009 ICC World Twenty20]],<ref> [http://www.cricketeurope4.net/T20WCQ2008/index.shtml ICC World T20 Qualifier 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080806025747/http://www.cricketeurope4.net/T20WCQ2008/index.shtml |date= 6 August 2008 }} CricketEurope. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> where they shocked host England at Lord's.<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/wt202009/content/story/407598.html Tom de Grooth leads Netherlands to famous win] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
After years of stagnation, the women's game is also developing rapidly in the Netherlands. Recently, the women's team outshone the men's team and they were given [[Test cricket]] status by the ICC in 2007 unlike their male counterparts. They played their inaugural Test match against South Africa Women in 2007.
The Dutch team qualified for the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]] by coming third in the [[2009 ICC World Cup Qualifier]].<ref> [http://iccworldcupqualifier.yahoo.net/ ICC World Cup Qualifier 2009] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5hmidXdEI?url=http://iccworldcupqualifier.yahoo.net/ |date=25 June 2009 }} Yahoo-Cricket (Official Website). Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> They did not make much of an impression, losing all of their matches, but giving England a fright in [[Nagpur]], where Ryan ten Doeschate smashed 119 runs.<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/icc_cricket_worldcup2011/content/story/502448.html England survive ten Doeschate brilliance] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
2010 turned out to be a memorable year for Dutch cricket as they defeated to Test-playing nations in the form of Bangladesh and Zimbabwe.
The Netherlands cricket team are currently participating in the [[ICC Intercontinental Cup|Intercontinental Cup]] and [[Intercontinental Cup One-Day]] while the women's team won the [[2011 Women's European Championship Twenty20]].<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/current/series/523708.html Women's European Championship Twenty20 2011] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> More recently, they participated in the [[2011 ICC Women's World Cup Qualifier]] where they came third in Group A, thus gaining both ODI Status and World Cup participation.<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/womens-world-cup-qualfier-2011/content/current/series/527926.html 2011 ICC Women's World Cup Qualifier] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
==Name Change== Before 1958 it was known as the Nederlandse Cricket Bond or the Dutch Cricket Board. After receiving a Royal charter in 1958, a "Royal" was added before the board's name known simply as [[Koninklijk]]e in Dutch. The following names have been for the board in their history:- * Nederlandse Cricket Bond (Dutch Cricket Board) * [[Koninklijk]]e Nederlandse Cricket Bond (Royal Dutch Cricket Board)
==Competitions== As well as maintaining Dutch international sides, the KNCB is also responsible for managing the regional domestic competitions. The following domestic competitions are organized in the Netherlands:- * [[Topklasse (cricket)|Topklasse]] * [[Hoofdklasse (cricket)|Hoofdklasse]] * [[Eerste Klasse (cricket)|Eerste Klasse]] * Topklasse Twenty20 Cup In addition, a number of youth programs as well as ladies programs are organized in the Netherlands.<ref> [http://www.kncb.nl/index.php?option=com_k2&view=itemlist&layout=category&Itemid=451 Evenementen en Toernooien] KNCB (''This page is in Dutch.''). Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
==Women's cricket== The Netherlands Women's Team was traditionally weak but in the last few years, they have made tremendous development, gaining Test status and out showing the men in recent times.
==Sponsorship== [[Amul]] was the official sponsor of the Dutch cricket team during the [[2011 Cricket World Cup]].<ref> [http://www.sportzpower.com/?q=content/dutch-cricket-announces-amul-world-cup-sponsor Dutch Cricket announces Amul as World Cup sponsor] SportzPower. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref> More recently, the KNCB had a ground-breaking sponsorship with leading Dutch bank [[ABN AMRO]], with chief executive [[Richard M. Cox|Richard Cox]] announcing that with this partnership, by the [[2015 Cricket World Cup]], they can contract professionally many players. It is a four-year deal running till 2016.<ref> [http://www.espncricinfo.com/netherlands/content/story/548407.html Netherlands gain sponsorship deal] ESPNCricinfo. Retrieved 12 January 2012</ref>
==See also==
*[[Dutch cricket team]] *[[Dutch women's cricket team]] *[[Cricket in the Netherlands]] *[[North Sea Pro Series]]
==External links== *[http://www.kncb.nl/ Official Site] *[http://www.cricketeurope4.net/NETHERLANDS/GENERAL/timeline.shtml CricketEurope Dutch cricket timeline] *[http://www.espncricinfo.com/netherlands/content/current/team/15.html Netherlands Profile – Cricinfo] *[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Countries/20.html Netherlands Profile – CricketArchive]

revision.text:
{{Expand list|date=August 2012}} [[File:SomeWheatiesBoxes.jpg|thumb|right|234px|Some Wheaties boxes with athletes or teams on the packaging, from the late 1990s.]] In 1934, the [[breakfast cereal]] [[Wheaties]] began the practice of including pictures of [[sportsperson|athletes]] on its packaging to coincide with its [[slogan]], "The Breakfast of Champions." In its original form, athletes were depicted on the sides or back of the cereal box, though in 1958 Wheaties began placing the pictures on the front of the box. The tradition has included hundreds of athletes from many different sports, and also team depictions.
This article lists the athletes or teams depicted on Wheaties boxes, along with the year(s) of depiction and sport played. This list is not all-inclusive, and athletes may have been shown together with teams and groups, or on the sides, back, or front of the box. Most athletes appeared on the standard Wheaties box, while others appeared on the Honey Frosted Wheaties (HFW), Crispy Wheaties 'n' Raisins (CWR), Wheaties Energy Crunch (WEC), or Wheaties Fuel (WF) boxes.

revision.text:
The '''Ms. International''' [[female bodybuilding]] contest was considered to be the second-most prestigious competition for [[female bodybuilding|female bodybuilders]] (second only to the [[Ms. Olympia]] competition), from its inception in 1986 through 2013. It was first held in 1986 by the [[International Federation of BodyBuilders]] (IFBB.). In 1987 the IFBB allowed the [[Amateur Athletic Union]] (AAU) to sanction the Ms. International as an amateur event. In 1988 the contest was again sanctioned by the IFBB. From 1989 on, the contest was part of the [[Arnold Sports Festival]]. The top all-time winners are [[Iris Kyle]] with seven titles and followed by [[Yaxeni Oriquen-Garcia]] with five titles. The only amateur to win the overall title was [[Kathy Segal]]. In 2013, it was announced that IFBB would drop the Ms. International from 2014 IFBB Pro Schedule.{{cite web|url=http://siteok.net/d/iron_man_usa_pdf/2009-06.pdf |title=2014 IFBB Pro Schedule |date=November 27, 2013 |publisher=musculardevelopment |accessdate=December 4, 2013 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527220959/http://siteok.net/d/iron_man_usa_pdf/2009-06.pdf |archivedate=May 27, 2014 }} == History == === 1986–1988 === The first Ms. International was held in 1986, and was sanctioned by the [[International Federation of BodyBuilders]] (I.F.B.B.). The contest was held in conjunction with the men’s event, which was called the IFBB Pro World Championship. Ben Weider proclaimed that the top six finishers would qualify for IFBB pro status, and be invited to compete at the 1986 IFBB Pro World in Toronto. The 1986 and 1988 Ms. Internationals were designated as pro-am contests, and top amateurs were also invited to compete. In 1987, the Ms. International was an amateur event sanctioned by the AAU. In 1988, [[Jim Lorimer (promoter)|Jim Lorimer]] and [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] felt the women’s competition should become a regular event along with the men’s.{{cite web|url=http://siteok.net/d/iron_man_usa_pdf/2009-06.pdf |title=The Ms. International |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140527220959/http://siteok.net/d/iron_man_usa_pdf/2009-06.pdf |archivedate=May 27, 2014 }} === 1989–1999 === Since 1989, the men’s Pro World Championship was renamed the Arnold Schwarzenegger Classic and the Ms. International become part of The [[Arnold Classic|Arnold Classic Weekend]]. That same year Tonya Knight had to forfeit both her placing and prize money from the 1988 and 1989 Ms. International when it was found out that she used someone else to take her drug test at the 1989 Ms. Olympia. The first most narrowest victory came in 1991 when Tonya Knight topped Anja Schreiner by a score of 30 to 32. There has been some controversy at the 1992 Ms. International. [[Anja Schreiner]] and [[Paula Bircumshaw]] both had the same body height, however Paula had much more muscle and weight (162 lbs). The judges regulated her to eighth place and the judges did not, as custom, called out out the top ten competitors on stage before announcing the winners. However this time, they only announced the top six competitors on stage in order to prevent Paula back on stage. The audience rioted over this decision and changed Paula's name. Paula did come back on stage only to give the judges the middle finger. Because of this she was given a year's suspension. In 1996, [[Kim Chizevsky-Nicholls]] became the first to win both Ms. International and [[Ms. Olympia]] in the same year. === 2000–2005 === The 2000 contest saw the introduction of weight classes, with a [[posedown]] between the two class winners to decide the overall championship. In 2004, Iris Kyle won her first heavyweight and overall Ms. Intentional. In 2005, Iris skipped the Ms. International, and focused defending her Olympia title, allowing Yaxeni Oriquen-Garcia to win. === 2006–2013 === The contest reverted to the single, open-class format in 2006. In 2006 and 2007, Iris won both Ms. Internationals. In 2007, the [[National Physique Committee|NPC]] [[Arnold Amateur]] was created as part of the Arnold Classic Weekend, which contained [[amateur]] women's bodybuilding. The Arnold Amateur Ms. International, unlike Arnold Classic Ms. International, contains weight classes. From 2007 to 2010 the Arnold Amateur Ms. International contained three weight classes, lightweight, middleweight, and heavyweight. The overall winner of the Amateur Ms. International win an IFBB pro card. In 2011, the middleweight was removed. There was a bit of a controversy in the 2008 Ms. International. Iris was placed 7th due to "bumps" on her gluts which according to head IFBB judge, Sandy Ranalli, “distortions in her physique.”,{{cite web|url=http://thinksteroids.com/news/iris-kyle-discusses-ms-international-results-with-pro-bodybuilding-weekly/|title=Iris Kyle Discusses Ms International Results with Pro Bodybuilding Weekly|publisher=MESO-Rx|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140108094607/http://thinksteroids.com/news/iris-kyle-discusses-ms-international-results-with-pro-bodybuilding-weekly/|archivedate=2014-01-08|df=}} The second most narrowest victory in Ms. International history came at the 2008 Ms. International, when Yaxeni Oriquen-Garcia edged runner-up Dayana Cadeau, by the score of 30 to 32. Iris Kyle rebounded at the 2009 Ms. International, which she won. Iris went on to win both the 2010 and 2011 Ms. International. Due to a leg injury Iris could not compete in the 2012 Ms. International, which was won by Yaxeni Oriquen-Garcia. In 2013, Iris Kyle won back her Ms. International title. On June 7, 2013, event promoter of the Arnold Sports Festival, [[Jim Lorimer (promoter)|Jim Lorimer]], announced that in 2014, the Arnold Classic 212 professional men’s bodybuilding division would replace the Ms. International women’s bodybuilding competition at the 2014 Arnold Sports Festival. Lorimer, in a statement, said “The Arnold Sports Festival was proud to support women’s bodybuilding through the Ms. International for the past quarter century, but in keeping with demands of our fans, the time has come to introduce the Arnold Classic 212 beginning in 2014. We are excited to create a professional competitive platform for some of the IFBB Pro League’s most popular competitors.”{{cite web|url=http://www.hardbodynews.com/2013/06/07/ms-international-dropped-from-2014-arnold-sports-festival/#sthash.IxIPPWAR.dpbs|title=Ms. International Dropped from 2014 Arnold Sports Festival|date=June 7, 2013|publisher=Hard Body News|accessdate=December 4, 2013}} === 2018 === On January 5, 2018, Beth Mandyck, a female bodybuilder, filed a sex discrimination lawsuit with the city of [[Columbus, Ohio]] over the IFBB cancelling the Ms. International from the Arnold Sports Festival. She has also started a [[change.org]] petition. Her complaint has been backed by Iris Kyle, [[Nancy Hogshead-Makar]], former Olympic gold medalist and the CEO of Champion Women, an advocacy group for women in sports, and [[Women's Sports Foundation]].[https://www.nbcnews.com/news/sports/female-bodybuilder-alleges-gender-discrimination-arnold-sports-festival-n844751 Female bodybuilder alleges gender discrimination at Arnold Sports Festival] == Winners == === Ms. International Overall Winner, by Year === {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align: left;" ! Year !! {{update|date= June 2018}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Olympic Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Olympic Complex of Oran.jpg | caption = '''[[CAF Elite stadium|CAF]]''' {{rating|4|4}} | fullname = | former_names = | location = Belgaïd, [[Bir El Djir]]
[[Oran]], [[Algeria]] | coordinates = {{Coord|35.728435|-0.549277|region:DZ_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1 June 2010 | built = 2010–2018 | opened = {{Start date and years ago|df=yes|2018|12|1}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Ministry of Youth and Sport | operator = Ministry of Youth and Sport | surface = [[Lawn|Grass]] | scoreboard = | cost = 142.3 millions [[United States dollar|US$]] | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = [[China Metallurgical Group Corporation]] | capacity = {{formatnum: 40143}} | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = {{convert|105|by|68|m|yards}} | acreage = | tenants = [[MC Oran]] (2018–) ''planned''
[[Algeria national football team|Algeria national team]] (2018–) ''planned'' }} '''Olympic Stadium (Oran)''' ({{Lang-ar|الملعب الأولمبي (وهران)}}) is a multi-use [[stadium]] in Belgaïd, [[Bir El Djir]] in the suburb of [[Oran]], [[Algeria]], that is currently under construction. Once completed in 2016, it will be used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and will host the home matches of [[MC Oran]], replacing their current [[Ahmed Zabana Stadium]]. It will have a capacity of 40,143 people. The stadium is a part of the '''Olympic Complex of Oran'''. it will be used as the opening and closing ceremony venue of the [[2021 Mediterranean Games]]. ==History== ===Construction=== [[File:Stade Abdelkader Freha.png|left|200px|thumb|Stadium under construction]] On December 20, 2006, planned the project of construction of the Olympic Complex. The stadium was planned for a capacity of 75,000 seats but was reduced to 40.000.{{cite web |url=http://www.vitaminedz.com/son-etude-a-ete-presentee-hier-a-l-hemicycle-de-la-wilaya-d/Articles_0_131120_31_1.html |title=Le stade olympique amputé de 35.000 places |work=La Voix de l'Oranie |publisher=Sofiane |date=December 21, 2006 |accessdate= }} On December 5, 2011, the minister of Youth and Sports, El Hachemi Djiar, announced that the stadium would be completed before the end of 2012.[http://www.lequotidien-oran.com/index.php?news=5161248 Djiar à Oran: Le stade olympique livré avant fin 2012]; Le Quotidien d'Oran, December 5, 2011 He also added that the entire project would be finished in 2015. But due to delays in construction work, the complex will be finished in 2018. ===Name of the stadium=== In 2014, M. [[Mohamed Raouraoua]] president of the [[Algerian Football Federation]] suggested that the stadium can take the name of the former legendary footballer of [[MC Oran]] and of the national team [[Abdelkader Fréha]].[https://www.dzairnews.com/articles/elwatan-sport-le-nouveau-stade-d-oran-sera-baptise-abdelkader-freha Le nouveau stade d’Oran sera baptisé Abdelkader Fréha] - DzairNews, May 22, 2014. ==See also== {{portal|Association football}} *[[List of football stadiums in Algeria]] *[[List of African stadiums by capacity]] *[[List of association football stadiums by capacity]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20061111151017/http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_menu/past_future/pictures/future_stadiums/oran_mco.shtml Future stadium images] at worldstadiums.com {{DEFAULTSORT:Abdelkader Freha Stadium}} [[Category:Football venues in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports venues in Oran]] [[Category:MC Oran|Stadium]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Algeria]] [[Category:Stadiums under construction]] {{Algeria-sports-venue-stub}}
